They are devoted to their commander and religion, they have hing morale and are very difficult to force off the battlefield. Despite having firearms they usually use it to start the fight and then move on to close combat.

3 plastic miniatures
6 Character cards including three cards exclusive for this expansion: 2x Janissary Veteran and Janissary Odabasi
9 item cards

-description from publisher's website

name: Bolt Action: Island Assault!
description:
The battles of World War Two ravaged the entire world.
Where the Band of Brothers starter set is very much concerned with the European Theatre in the wake of D-Day, this starter set shifts focus to the Pacific, pitting the United States Marine Corps against Japanese Island defenders in some of the most brutal and hard-fought battles of the War.

This starter set is focussed on the island-hopping campaigns enacted by the US to reclaim Japanese advances.
Unlike the land war that raged in Europe, North Africa, and the Soviet Union, where vast armies of tanks and infantry could manoeuvre and fight over large tracts of open ground, the Pacific campaign was fought mostly on a series of relatively small islands, densely packed with jungles and protected by the sea. Each island had to be landed on, fought for, and the defenders rooted out of, individually.

Containing two opposing forces set amongst the many islands in the Pacific theatre, Island Assault! contains the Bolt Action 2nd edition rules as well as a scenario booklet guiding you through your first steps in the game.

Before long you’ll be adding to your new army and wreaking havoc on your foes be they fighting for Uncle Sam or the Emperor!

-description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: World War III: Team Yankee – West German
description:
World War III: Team Yankee – West German offers:

Background on the West German army,1. Panzerdivision, 3. Panzerdivision,Kampfgruppe Müller, and Panzerlehrbrigade 9;
Instructions on how to build Leopard 2A5,Leopard 2, & Leopard 1 Panzer, Marder 2,Marder 1, & M113 Panzergrenadier, & three different Panzeraufklärungs companies;
Three Scenarios to test your skills with your West German force;
A detailed painting guide to help you prepare your West Germans for combat;


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: World War III: Team Yankee – West German Starter Force: Panzeraufklärungs Kompanie
description: World War III: Team Yankee – West German Starter Force: Panzeraufklärungs Kompanie, Panzer Reconnaissance Company.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: აღმოაჩინე საქართველო (Discover Georgia)
description:
აღმოაჩინე საქართველო , Discover Georgia

Players have to travel to different parts of Georgia and visit different cities

Each turn players draw cards and attempt to claim routes to achieve their objective (cards).
The objective cards indicate destinations between cities in Georgia and bordering countries.
Player scores points by claiming routes (the longer the more points) and achieving their objective (the further away, the more points scored at end of game).

The goal is to visit as many places as possible to earn more points. The player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Connections, Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Fishing Boats (fan expansion to Carcassonne)
description:
The rivers around Carcassonne provide a bounty of fish. Although some of the anglers prefer to fish
from the shores of the rivers, there are others who will take a small boat out to the middle of the
river to fish. Fishing boats can be used like Wagons for the roads.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Medieval

name: Post of Honour: Wargames rules for the War of the Austrian Succession & the Seven Years' War 1740-1763
description:
Post of Honour – Wargames rules for the War of the Austrian Succession & the Seven Years War 1740-1763 is designed for a ‘classic’ historical wargame.

Features:

12-20 units per side,
game lasts a couple of hours,
it can be played at home or at your wargaming club.
the overall commander controls 3 to 5 brigades and up to 2 independent units.


The rules were developed for games using 25-30mm figures, and conversion to other scales is easy.

Turn Sequence
Each turn has 5 phases:
1- Initiative. The winner elects to be side A or side B.
2- Movement. Side A moves (generals move last), then side B moves (generals last).
3- Firing. Simultaneous fighting.
4- Close Combat. Simultaneous fighting. Initiative winner chooses order of combats.
5- Generalship & Rallying. Simultaneous. Generalship first, then rally checks.
Morale may need to be checked in the movement, firing, or close combat phases.

—description from the rulebook
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Toerkk
description:
Toerkk is a fast paced fantasy card game with innovative mechanics for 2 to 4 players. Play as one of the dwarven warlords and win the game either by digging out 20 levels of ground to find a mythical torc buried deep down in the heart of the mountain or simply by eliminating your opponents by reducing their health points to 0 using your warriors, abilities and spells. But beware, land of Bokvyst is a mysterious place, every turn you will have to face the powers which rule this area. You have to plan your strategy on the go as the situation in the playground changes with every swing of a hammer.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Closed Drafting, Dice Rolling, Race, Team-Based Game

name: Ryder: The Card Game
description:
A game where luck is cast aside in honour of memory, strategy and, after some time, skill. Set in the time of knights & wizards.

Battle your friends to earn the most tributes and buy your passage home.

Each player has 4 cards dealt to them, face down and takes it in turns to combat their foes around the table. You may look at your cards but cannot move the position of them. You select your cards to attack other players face down cards and then begin the process of endeavoring to remember where all the cards are, who to attack, what skills to play on opponents to mess with their gameplay etc.

Designed to remove the "Luck" element of card games and instead grant the winner victory via superior memory or strategic skills. With additional elements such as War Cry's and individual card skills, there's plenty to laugh about while playing.

–description from the designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Deduction, Fighting, Medieval, Memory
mechanics: Action/Event, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Deduction, Hand Management, Memory, Move Through Deck

name: Dungeon Degenerates: Guttergeist
description:
Guttergeist is a single Lowlands Monster, included with the second issue of the official Dungeon Degenerates zine: Die Wurst.

It has the following stats:
Name: Guttergeist
Class: Heretic * Weird
Value: 1 XP, 0 gold
Target: Lowest MAG
Attack: 2
Armor: 0
HP: 4
Abilities: Fear [black], Evade, Ghostly
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Irr-elephant
description:
Irr-elephant is finally here; the premier elephant stacking wooden game!

First, stack up the elephants higher and higher on progressively more precarious perches. Then, once you've completed your teetering tower, roll the die, and remove an elephant whose color matches the die. But be careful, if the elephants come crashing down, you lose!

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game
mechanics: Physical Removal, Single Loser Game, Stacking and Balancing

name: Final Fusion
description:
Mix two unique factions and lead them through a constant conflict in a tight space. Colonize, upgrade and dominate to be the first to perform Final Fusion.

Final Fusion is a 2-4 (5 with expansion) player competitive game where you become a villainous commander in charge of two unique factions. To win you must perform a Final Fusion - an action that leaves you vulnerable unless you gather Void Particles first. Wait too long, and see other players win the game.

Constant conflict from the first round
Unique victory condition, not another point salad
Elaborate alien miniatures, not another bags of spacecrafts
Beautiful locations instead of balls floating in space
28 Starting Faction Combinations (66 with expansion)


Short description of Gameplay
Final Fusion is a 2-5 players 60-90m conflict-driven space game, where each player leads an alliance of two alien races. Both races contribute a set of unique cards (used for actions and conflict resolution) and their Fleet (represented by a miniature with a functional tray to put your armies on).

From the first turn of the game, you partake in a “Fistfight in a space elevator” of a kind. All around you’ll have bloodthirsty neighbors waiting to strike. It is crucial to pick your battles and keep tabs on opponents - to know when to push back and when to tactically retreat.
The aim of the game is to achieve the eponymous Final Fusion, a feat of cosmic engineering on par with building a death star. This task requires getting Void Particles (VP for short), either by extracting them, colonizing locations, or dominating your opponents. While at it players strategically buy new technologies for their decks, gain Traits, and man their fleets to prepare for massive space battles.

Beware! The more VP you have, the easier it is to complete Final Fusion, but if you wait too long, another player might initiate the Fusion before you!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Let's PLAAY Jai-Alai
description:
Let's PLAAY Jai-Alai re-creates the experience of hanging out at a jai-alai fronton in Connecticut, Florida or Las Vegas in the 1970s and can be played in any one of multiple game modes. There's the solo betting mode, where it's just you and your wagering savvy matching wits with tonight's card. Or, get friends together and make a night of it, each making your own bets to see who's the top dog. Nobody available tonight? You can still make it a party, matching wits with one or more of our card stock fronton-fans, who will place their own bets as you place yours. Or, you can skip the betting entirely and create your own professional jai-alai tour with a regular season, playoffs and a league champion!

—description from the publisher

name: Defence of Rorke's Drift
description:
A free online print-and-play solitaire 'worker placement' game, simulating the famous British defence of Rorke's Drift on the night of 22 January 1879 at the beginning of the Zulu War.

The player, representing the British, must assign each of 4 dice to one of three actions: fighting off the Zulu attackers, putting out fires, or progressing the passage of time until dawn/relief arrives. Successful, die rolls kill Zulus, protect the defences or mark the passage of time respectively. Any Zulus not killed then inflict casualties on the British.

The game ends in a British victory if the time marker reaches the 10th box on its track, and a British defeat (massacre) if the Zulus inflict 10 casualties.

The game takes 5 mins to play and comes with a 2-player option and several optional rules.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Solo / Solitaire Game, Worker Placement

name: Black Seas: Large Xebec
description:
A Xebec is a two- or three-masted vessel usually found in the Mediterranean that was used mostly for trading. It had a long overhanging bowsprit, an aftset mizzen mast and lateen sails.

Favoured by Barbary Corsairs (Muslim pirates operating off the coast of North Africa) and Algerian Berber corsairs, early xebecs had two masts, whilst later examples had three. The ships were generally smaller than frigates of the period, both in terms of displacement and the number of guns they carried.

The modified ships were oftentimes faster than their victims owing to a narrower floor, and their lateen sails meant that it could sail at great speed close to the wind – lending them a great advantage in pursuit or escape. Xebecs armed in this way would mount between 300 and 400 men and would mount between 16 and 40 guns.

The design was not without its disadvantages; the ships fared poorly in rough weather and high seas, and the sails were vulnerable to enemy dismantling fire. A wise captain would therefore need to pick their battles wisely, and use their ship’s superior manoeuvrability to avoid unwinnable confrontations and instead prey on the weak – striking swiftly to overwhelm their prey and withdraw equally as quickly.

As well as uses in piracy there were some uses of xebecs in national navies as light warships – often as a direct counter to the pirates themselves. The advantages of speed and manoeuvrability did not go unnoticed by coastal traders either – especially those who favoured speed and draft over cargo capacity.

One of the most famous single-ship actions in all of naval history involved a Xebec. On 6 May 1801, the British sloop Speedy defeated the Spanish Xebec-frigate El Gamo. This engagement is the inspiration for many examples of literary naval fiction, perhaps most notably Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander.

This pack includes one large Xebec for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for its use with the included ship card.

–description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Wargame

name: Black Seas: Xebec Squadron
description:
A Xebec is a two- or three-masted vessel usually found in the Mediterranean that was used mostly for trading. It had a long overhanging bowsprit, an aftset mizzen mast and lateen sails.

Favoured by Barbary Corsairs (Muslim pirates operating off the coast of North Africa) and Algerian Berber corsairs, early xebecs had two masts, whilst later examples had three. The ships were generally smaller than frigates of the period, both in terms of displacement and the number of guns they carried.

The modified ships were oftentimes faster than their victims owing to a narrower floor, and their lateen sails meant that it could sail at great speed close to the wind – lending them a great advantage in pursuit or escape. Xebecs armed in this way would mount between 300 and 400 men and would mount between 16 and 40 guns.

The design was not without its disadvantages; the ships fared poorly in rough weather and high seas, and the sails were vulnerable to enemy dismantling fire. A wise captain would therefore need to pick their battles wisely, and use their ship’s superior manoeuvrability to avoid unwinnable confrontations and instead prey on the weak – striking swiftly to overwhelm their prey and withdraw equally as quickly.

As well as uses in piracy there were some uses of xebecs in national navies as light warships – often as a direct counter to the pirates themselves. The advantages of speed and manoeuvrability did not go unnoticed by coastal traders either – especially those who favoured speed and draft over cargo capacity.

One of the most famous single-ship actions in all of naval history involved a Xebec. On 6 May 1801, the British sloop Speedy defeated the Spanish Xebec-frigate El Gamo. This engagement is the inspiration for many examples of literary naval fiction, perhaps most notably Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander.

This pack includes a squadron of three xebecs for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for their use with the included ship cards.
categories: Age of Reason, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Wargame

name: Letter Rush
description:
In Letter Rush, 2 players will rush through a pile of letter tokens in a fast-paced color matching word game. Play for points or ability cards that'll give you an edge against your opponent. All cards have colored squares that will match the colors of letter tokens. The players must find letter tokens in the required color patterns, along with making a complete word to claim cards. The player with the most points after 3-5 rounds will win!

—description from the designer
categories: Educational, Party Game, Real-time, Word Game
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Interrupts, Matching, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Pattern Building, Race, Real-Time, Single Loser Game, Speed Matching, Spelling, Take That

name: Snowdonia: Time-travelling Police Box
description:
A single-card promo of a time-travelling police box "train", originally available at UKGE 2018 on the Surprised Stare stand.

Also available as a PnP from Tony Boydells blog:
https://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/67696/time-and-relative-d...

All excavation and building spaces are available to you when you excavate/build (even if they are out of sequence or have not been 'reached' yet).

When you take the Lay Track action, you may lay track on any available track card (empty in most scenarios, full in The Daffodil Line) out of the usual sequence too.

The owner of this train may pay 1 Coal to get their Third Labourer companion out of the Pub.

Note: Included in the Snowdonia: Deluxe Master Set but with different artwork and title (Time Machine)

name: MadBlox
description: This game is based around the idea of the wooden blocks game in which players have to take blocks out of the tower without knocking them down. The twist that MadBlox offers is that each block comes with two possible challenges for the player to choose from. Thus, after carefully taking out the block from the tower, the player has to complete one of the two challenges depicted on the piece. If the player refuses to do so, they have to take a shot.

name: Kontraband: More Salvage and Survival
description:
KONTRABAND - More Salvage and Survival - An expansion for Osprey Wargames Zona Alfa, Salvage and Survival in the Exclusion Zone.

Designed for Solo and Cooperative games, Kontraband introduces more detail for player characters, new equipment, new enemies, and mission objectives.
With a five-part sample campaign - Zone Ravens - it's time for your Veterans to explore high-threat locations deep in the Exclusion Zone.

Grab your gear. The Zone is calling.

NOTE: This is not a stand-alone game. You need the Zona Alfa rules to use this book.

– Description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Anno Domini 1666: Order of the Broken Cross – Knechts
description:
The Knechts of the order are devout cultists. By day, some of them pose as regular members of the Teutonic Order. When carrying out missions for their true masters, The Order of the Broken Cross, they wear masks and hooded cloaks to conceal their identities. They use crossbows instead of forearms, since they are far quieter.

3 detailed plastic miniatures
6 character cards
9 item cards

name: Unraveled
description:
A 1 vs many evidence analysis game.

The conspirator has an agenda, and it all hinges on one key piece of evidence. The evidence cards comes in three different types, colors, and fills, for a total of 27 unique cards. One is the key evidence the conspirator must hide in plain sight.


Type Fill Colors
Document Solid Salmon
Testimony Spotty Navy Blue
Exhibit Hollow Golden

The sleuths can examine the evidence, confirming if it shares any traits with the key evidence. But every move gives the conspirator more time and fuel to actuate their plan.

To complicate things, some of the sleuths may discover that they're loyal to the conspirator, and instead wish to enable their plot, and sabotage the investigation.
mechanics: Deduction, Matching, Roles with Asymmetric Information

name: Drakar och demoner: Gigant Fältslagsregler
description: In 1987, the expansion "Gigant" came for the Swedish role-playing game "Drakar och demoner". The expansion contains rules for field battles that can be played with the role-playing game or separately. All that is needed is paper, pencil and dice. You can play with troops consisting of elves, dwarves, wolfmen, ratmen, centaurs, goblin wolfriders, lizardmen and more. The battles goes down in the Swedish fantasy world Ereb Altor.

name: Stuart Asquith's Wargaming 18th Century Battles
description:
This book focuses on one of the Stuart Asquith's key interests, 18th century warfare.
The attractions of the period are described, along with nine accounts of key battles 1704-1760. These battles include:

Battle of the Schellenberg (1704)
Battle of Ramillies (1706)
Battle of Sheriffmuir (1715)
Battle of Mollwitz (1741)
Battle of Soor (1745)
Battle of Falkirk (1746)
Battle of Plassey (1757)
Battle of Minden (1759)
Battle of Warburg (1760)


Of course, the book would not be complete without a set of classic 'Old School' wargaming rules.
The obvious choice was Stuart Asquith's popular wargaming rules for Malburian Warfare 1702-1714.

This work is published as part of The History of Wargaming Project range of books that aim to document the development of wargaming.

–description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Selsia
description:
You are a spaceship captain and you cruise your ship between planets to create your own destiny. You can perform different kinds of jobs. You can be a bounty hunter or sabotage others. You can deliver cargo or perform heroic acts. You want to become famous and it is up to you to decide how to reach your objectives. You might get involved into politics and decide to support the terrans or the Aeroneans. Or you might ignore both and try to pick your own quest. The possibilities are limitless in Selsia, but one thing remains constant: you must keep getting stronger! Upgrade your spaceship and recruit crew members to help you reach your goals.

Selsia is a 1-4 players game that takes 30-75 minutes to play. Players will compete throughout the game for fame. The player with the most fame points wins. In Selsia, the following mechanisms are utilized: action selection, area control, pickup and delivery, rondel movement and dice rolling.

In the start of the game, each player get their own spaceships. Later on, players will have the chance to upgrade different parts of their spaceships using a catalog of at least 28 unique upgrades that allow different strategies and provide a high replay value. Each upgrade slots into the player board based on its type giving a nice visual appeal and a sense of advancement. Players will install new weapons, better defense systems, stronger battery units, better engines, ...

Selsia uses various unique and easy to grasp mechanisms. Players have to move their spaceships and perform an action, it's that simple. The rules are easy to learn, but making the right decision is not so easy. There are many strategies available to choose from, and the best of them all is revealed only at the end of each game. And the icing on the cake is a novel, rewarding and exciting combat system.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Contracts, Dice Rolling, Movement Points, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Rondel, Solo / Solitaire Game, Tech Trees / Tech Tracks, Variable Player Powers

name: A Song of Ice & Fire: Tabletop Miniatures Game – Stormcrow Dervishes
description:
Stormcrow Dervishes represent some of their best-trained veteran troops. These hardened veterans can move rapidly despite medium armor, and attack exposed elements, even at long distances across the battlefield. As with all Stormcrows, a little extra coins goes a long way, and these veterans didn't get where they are by taking coin without delivering added performance. They can engage swiftly from surprising distances, strike hard, then fade back to the relative safety of their own lines. If pinned, they can hold their own against even heavy troops, though not for long. Staying mobile is their best defense.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Novel-based, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Measurement Movement, Worker Placement with Dice Workers

name: Dark Domains: 2020 Lab Rat Gift Cards
description:
A set of six Obscure Arcana card that can be added to the base game's fortune card mix.

Includes: Aeon, TheUniverse, The Void, Aether, The Four Winds, and Time

These were originally sent as gifts to the Lab Rats of Laboratory H.

name: Murder Bunnies: The Killer Card Game
description: Murder Bunnies is a 2-player strategy game where every ability has a trigger, and every turn could be your last. Capture, Spawn, Move, or Attack enemy bunnies on the field using your action points to maximize your murder and earn your share of the Carrot Bounty. But be careful - every bunny has an ability with a trigger built in, so plan your moves wisely.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Sad Days of Battle: The Battle of Jarama, February 6-27, 1937
description:
“There's a valley in Spain called Jarama. it's a place that we all know so well. It was there that we fought against the fascists. We saw a peaceful valley turn to hell.”—Excerpt from Woody Guthrie’s song Battle of Jarama.

After failing to take Madrid in November, Francisco Franco ordered his forces to cut off the former capital city and now symbol of Republican resistance by taking the roads south of the city linking it to the Republican government in Valencia. The attack over the Jarama river was to be coordinated with the Italian’s offensive to the north and east of the city along the Guadalajara river. However, the Italians were taking longer than anticipated to get their forces into positions, hindered by poor weather and abysmal planning. With growing impatience General Franco ordered his forces to attack, supported by the German Condor Legion as well as masses of new German tanks, artillery pieces and ample supplies of ordinance.

Can you do as well or better than your historical counterparts? Learn and enjoy!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: Potato Inferno!: Demonotized Spudtuber
description:
This is an expansion for Potato Inferno, including 25 new cards and 6 spud-tuber tokens!

Join the spud-tubers in the ups and downs of potato themed content!

Will you be demonetized? or dominate the Internet with the power of potatoes!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Educational, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game

name: Last Stand at Mistham: A Campaign for Sellswords and Spellslingers
description:
Goblins, orcs and ogres surround you.

Last Stand at Mistham is a simple, goblin-and-orc smashing campaign for the Sellswords and Spellslingers solo/coop fantasy miniatures rules.
Your heroes are tasked with stopping goblin attacks on Mistham, a peaceful village. A run of the mill job for seasoned heroes… but when the two daughters of the village chief are involved, the situation quickly becomes much more complicated.

Contents:

Five Scenarios for 1-6 players, each running a party of adventurers built on 60 to 150 points,
42 pages


—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Events, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Star Trek: The Next Generation Collectible Dice Game – Borg Sphere Starter Set
description:
Based on the Star Trek TNG First Contact movie. Five Rings Publishing Group released the game in a Federation and Borg starter pack.

This is the Borg Sphere Starter Set
Resistance is futile. This set enables you to command the Borg Sphere and assimilate all you encounter.
25 assorted 20mm polyhedral dice; three 6-sided, five 8-sided, six 10-sided, seven 12-sided and four 20-sided dice
The dice control your ship's warp core, reserve power, shield strength, phasers, quantum torpedos, damage control, impulse power and sensors
A full-color ship Bridge/control panel from which you command ship systems and personnel
A full color ship shield and icon chart, and a 24 page Basic Training(TM) instruction book and rules.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: The F. A. Cup Game
description:
In the game, you get 144 cards, split into 2 decks of Chances (really good scoring chances), and Half-Chances (long shot scoring chances). Teams are rated simply for goals scored and goals allowed, home and away. Each team is rated further for who scores the team's goals when a goal is scored.

Depending on the goals scored rating of the team and the goals allowed rating of the opponent, each team will get a certain number of possible chances per game. The trick is that not all those chances will come up in a game and, despite having more possible total chances in a match than the opposition, a streak of bad luck could lead to the big upset. Players roll two six sided dice, one to see if anything happens in that period of time (1 out of six times you get a Chance, 1 out of six you get a Half Chance, 4 out of six you get nothing ). You roll each half of the match until you run out of possible chances.

Example: one team has 7 chances, the other team has 3. There will be a total of 10 dice rolls to make up a single half of play. If you roll a 5 or 6, flip a FAC and a further roll of the dice will happen to determine the outcome.

The Chance and Half-Chance cards have descriptive play calls on them so you really get the feel of watching the highlights reel of a match. You will have high scoring shootouts and defensive stalemates.

Included are:

124 Team Indicator cards which are used to identify and rate the *128 competing teams;
16 dice of various colors which are used to determine the shots missed and the goals scored during the game. A team rating determines the number of dice rolled - a five might be a goal while a 6 is always a goal;
a Match Die Chart to cross-reference against the ratings for each team;
a Goal Misses Chart, which adds imagery;
a Goal Description Chart, which also adds to the imagery;
a Rule Book; and a description of how to convert the F. A. Cup system to various sized leagues.


The game also requires a deck of regular playing cards which you can order with the game or supply yourself.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Stat Check Resolution

name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar: Warcry – Scions of the Flame
description:
Even amongst the followers of the Ruinous Powers, the Scions of the Flame are zealots. These warriors worship the darkest fires of Aqshy, bringing their blazing wrath to bear on all they deem their enemies.

Sweep all before you with fire and fury – such is the way of the Scions of the Flame! This warband set allows you to field these Aqshian cultists in your battles, containing:


8 multipart plastic Scions of the Flame miniatures – 1 Blazing Lord, 1 Brazen Champion, 1 Inferno Priest, 1 Immolator, 2 Fireborn, and 2 Initiates, with a variety of weapons options
A Scions of the Flame abilities card, allowing you to unleash the distinctive and deadly battle tactics of this warband in your games
11 fighter cards for seeing your rules at a glance, plus divider cards for tracking your tokens


—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Alert! All Hands On Deck: Fleet Expansion
description:
Add a new fleet to your game with this expansion for Alert: All Hands on Deck (required for play).

Adds

5 new ships.
An optional Create Fleet Deck rule.
Special abilities are free now but you remove the active threat card from the game.


Create Fleet Deck
Instead of putting ships by the modifier value, pick any 3 ships and their order in the fleet deck.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: D-Day to Berlin: Six Panzer Armee – Scenario 1: The Battle of the Bulge
description:
6th Panzer Armee is a two or more player scenario for D-Day to Berlin depicting the northern shoulder of Hitler’s surprise attack Wacht am Rhein.
This was located in the Ardennes in December,1944, commonly known as the Battle of the Bulge.

In this scenario the area of concentration is roughly from Monschau to just north of St. Vith, from December 16th to the 19th, 1944 when the German attack still had a chance to cross the Meuse.

This scenario includes:

Customized Map
Order of Battle for both Allied and German forces
Special rules for the scenario
New rules for D-Day to Berlin


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Grid Coverage, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Memo Challenge
description:
An original memory game for everyone and for true champions of visual skill.

Memo Shuffle the cards and place them on the table face down to farm a 6x6 square. The youngest player turns 2 cards aver. If they are identical, the player wins them and keeps on playing. If the 2 cards are not identical, the player turns them back aver and it's the fallowing player's turn. The game ends when there are no more cards on the table, Whoever collects the most cards is the winner.

In Memo challenge The rules are the same as in the previous game.

At the beginning of the game though, the players decide on a joker shape (for instance a square) and a joker colour (for instance green). At the end of the game, one point is awarded for each card won and one extra point per card is awarded for joker symbols (shape and/or colour) on the cards (two squares = two extra points). The player with the highest score wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Memory, Party Game

name: Add Up
description:
Look at the rows of numbers, study the opponents and play the right card to have two equal sums.

Shuttle the cards and deal 3 to each player. Then place two "opening" cards face up on the table, placing one above the other on an imaginary line. The rest of the deck stays face down at disposal for the game.

The youngest player starts. Each player, when it's their turns, plays a card either on the top or the bottom row. lf the sum of the cards on the top row is the same as that on the bottom, the player who put the final card down, wins all the cards on the table, otherwise it is the following player's turn.

When a player puts down their card, they immediately draw another from the top of the deck in order to always have 3 cards in their hands. When a player wins all the cards on the table, two new "opening" cards are placed one above the other from the deck and the game continues. When there are no more cards left in the deck, the players play the cards they are still holding until they are gone. Whoever has the most cards at the end wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Math, Party Game

name: Close Quarter Battles: Waterloo
description:
Close Quarter Battles: Waterloo, a game of tactical combat set in the Napoleonic era. With this game, players will be able to recreate the famous assaults on the farms of La Haye Sainte and Hougoumont during the Battle of Waterloo on June 18, 1815. It hopes to demonstrate how ferocious the fighting was around these iconic locations that even today bear the scars of that famous day.

Indeed, the capture of these two farms became an obsession for the French, and thousands of Napoleon’s men would become casualties trying to wrest control of them from the smaller Anglo-Allied garrisons. The fighting was intense, often involving hand-to-hand combat, and raged for hours through woods, orchards, and finally into the farms. Both the attackers and defenders demonstrated incredible bravery and their efforts helped in no small way to determine the outcome of the battle.

—description from the publisher

name: Grim(m) World: Erste Schritte – Isegrim, der Wolf
description: Isegrim, the Wolf is the second mini expansion for Grim(m) World - Erste Schritte. This expansion consists of 9 cards and includes a wolf as a pet, which allows to play the game with 2 players. One player plays one of the four characters and the other player plays the wolf Isegrim.

name: Scouts of Æternia
description:
Scouts of Æternia is a game of tactical skirmishing for 1–4 players.

Explore one of the wilder parts of Æternia as scouts tasked with mapping the ground for your main force to move in and take control of a region lost to lawless robbers. Follow tips from your reconnaissance contacts to gather military intelligence in targeted locations while preventing enemy scouts from doing the same.

Scouts, represented by dice, move across a square grid made up of 9 map tiles. Combat can be sought out or avoided - when a Scout runs out of wounds, he is removed. Win by being the first to gather the necessary intelligence or by knocking your opponents' Scouts out of the game.

This is the first game set in the indigo woods and red soil of the fantasy world of Æternia.

- description by designer
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Moving Multiple Units, Solo / Solitaire Game, Square Grid, Team-Based Game

name: PinchanPlaf
description:
The game of combat puppets! Duel in a game of fencing, pop the rival's balloon and win the game!

You can control the sword and shield of your puppet using the correspoding handlebars. Manuever your weapons to pop your rival's balloon to win the duel.

—user summary

name: Caterpillar Filler
description:
You each control a caterpillar exploring a garden looking for delicious flowers to eat.

You must avoid the wasps and potentially other caterpillars while you scavenge for food.

On your turn you roll the die to see how many spaces you can move your caterpillar within the garden (a 16x16 grid). If you move your caterpillar onto a space with a flower token; your caterpillar will grow.

Caterpillars don’t just eat flowers; they can also chomp on other caterpillars. If you move onto another player’s caterpillar, you will grow while they will shrink (as you take a bite out of them).

Players can also gain wasp tokens to block (or trap) opponent’s caterpillars within the garden.

At the end of the game, the player with the largest caterpillar has enough energy to transform into a beautiful butterfly and wins!

—description from the designer

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Ninth Edition) Codex: Adepta Sororitas
description:
The Adepta Sororitas are the Chamber Militant, or armed fighting force, of the Adeptus Ministorum. Often known colloquially as the 'Sisters of Battle', their Order was created to defend the faithful and their places of worship, battling threats from daemons, xenos, and even heretical humans. With the opening of the Great Rift and the sundering of their Emperor's realm, new crusades brimming with Battle Sisters have struck out across the galaxy to bring judgement with flame, blade, and bolt.

Clad in thick suits of power armour and wielding weapons usually seen only among the Emperor's Angels of Death, the Adepta Sororitas take to the field with an unquenchable zeal. Empowered by their faith and capable of performing miraculous feats, the Battle Sisters march alongside mighty tanks and powerful mechanical warsuits to bring fire and fury to every corner of the galaxy. Along with inspirational photographs of stunningly painted models, you can delve into the background and lore of the Adepta Sororitas, and discover the rules that you need to field them in your games of Warhammer 40,000.

Inside this 128-page codex, you will find:

The history and origins of the Adepta Sororitas, detailing how they rose from a galaxy-spanning heresy to defend the Emperor's faith
A showcase of stunningly painted Citadel Miniatures that displays the martial liveries of their many Holy Orders
A vast range of datasheets providing tabletop rules for 34 units from the Adepta Sororitas army
A bounty of Stratagems, Relics, and Warlord Traits featuring updated favourites and brand new options for your army on the tabletop
Bespoke Crusade rules that allow you to embark upon a quest to raise your Canoness to the status of Living Saint
And more!


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Ninth Edition): Chapter Approved – Grand Tournament 2021 Mission Pack and Munitorum Field Manual 2021 MkII
description:
This year’s edition of Chapter Approved is the essential gaming toolbox for all fans of Warhammer 40,000 matched play. Whether you're a tournament regular or simply like to ensure your battles are always fought on an even footing, this is the essential supplement for matched play games of Warhammer 40,000.

Inside this 96-page softback book, you'll find:


Two mission packs, comprising nine missions each for Incursion- and Strike Force-scale battles, each designed to offer a different challenge to the players.
Guidelines for setting up and playing a matched play or Grand Tournament-level competitive game, including suggested battlefield size, time limit and how best to determine secondary objectives.
Updated secondary objectives. Some are entirely new, while others have been tweaked, or had the amount of Victory points they award adjusted.
And much, much more…


In addition, you'll also find a separate 56-page book – the Munitorum Field Manual Mk II – containing all the latest matched play points updates, painstakingly balanced and tuned in conjunction with major tournament organisers and our playtesters.

Whether you're looking to take your matched play gaming to a whole new level or are wanting to stay on the pulse with all the latest points value developments for every faction, Chapter Approved has something for you, and is a fitting guide to the incredible new edition of Warhammer 40,000.

Please note: the points values featured in the Munitorum Field Manual 2021 MkII for the Thousand Sons and Grey Knights are incorrect due to a delay in the release of their codexes. Until these codexes are released later in 2021, you can download the updated points values for the Thousand Sons and Grey Knights from the PDF found in the downloads tab. These points values cater for all the units from both of these factions and are designed to be used alongside their current codexes until their new books arrive.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: The Path of the Adventurers: The Unholy Crypt
description: This expansion brings 5 preset scenarios, a new location: the Crypt, a Dark Lord: the Necromancer, an Adventurer: the Paladin, 10 new skill cards, 5 new equipment cards and a brand new legendary set of equipment.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Quak Quak
description:
The front cover explains the whole game. Each player receives four frogs, which he jumps into the well. Whoever manages to do this first is the winner.

—user summary

name: Fistful of Lead: Horse & Musket – 2nd Edition
description:
These rules are designed to fight skirmishes during the black powder era.

This rulebook is extremely versatile because it easily covers many conflicts of the 18th and early 19th century; from Napoleonics to the War of Spanish Succession, and covers the wars in America: French Indian War, American War of Independence, War of 1812 and the American Civil War.

This 2nd edition brings the Horse & Musket genre into line with our Core System. It is a stand-alone game.

What else is included in the 2nd edition of Horse & Musket rules?

Full Color, 52 pages
Perfect Bound Cover
4 Exclusive New Scenarios


P.S. The Horse & Musket Custom Cards have NOT CHANGED.

–description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, American Civil War, American Revolutionary War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Ashigaru: 1567
description:
The 16th century was a time of strife for Japan. Its many clans were autonomous, headstrong and resistant to unification. The emperor thus began a competition for shogun between his two greatest samurai. You and an opponent will vie for the title as you coerce one village after another, searching for the three resources vital to the creation of the fighting infantry called Ashigaru – men, food and gold. Will you be able to unite the major clans, better your opponent and become shogun? Find out by playing all three games of Ashigaru:1567 – making wise decisions, using clever card management, and playing winning 3-Card Poker hands! (Note: This is the first in a series of low-cost games using the 3CP Game Engine™, which employs custom cards plus a user-supplied 52-card deck of standard playing cards.)

During the game, players try to win Ashigaru cards by playing 3-card poker hands from a standard deck. However, it's not as simple as it first appears. Since you get a new card every round, will you hold onto a pair of jacks, for example, hoping for a third -- making three-of-a-kind? Or break up two Aces to use one in a straight? A simple, easily memorized chart determines what Ashigaru cards you get -- and the better your winning hand, the better the cards you win.

There are three related games included, of easy to moderate complexity. All are simple to learn, fun to play and balanced, with a fairly high tension level.


Print & Play cards available in Files section.
Professionally produced card deck available at thegamecrafter.com.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Admiral: Naval clashes in the Second World War
description:
Admiral is a naval tabletop game, for two players, settled in the world war II, where each player commands ships from one of the six navy involved in the conflict: Kriegsmarine, Royal Navy, Regia Marina, Marine Nationale, U.S. Navy and Nippon Kaigun. This book provides you with all the rules you need to play, the features of all units involved and several missions to carry out.

The rules are for ships in 1:1850 scale but easily adaptable for ships in 1:2.400 and 1:3000 scale through a conversion table.
Each ships is identified by a number and a corresponding card and the game is divided in round.

At the start of each round each player create its activation deck secretly choosing the activation sequence of its ships, then make an Initiative trow by a D6.

First player reveal its first card and activate the corresponding ship: it will move and attack by a dice trow depending from the caliber of their guns (D6, D8, D10, D12). Then the second player will reveal its first card activating the corresponding ships and so on, until all unit will be activated.

The rule book includes rules for aircraft carriers, aircraft, submarine and other special type of units and contain a section for carry out a campaign.
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Measurement Movement, Movement Template, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Stat Check Resolution, Variable Player Powers

name: The Battle for Normandy, Deluxe Edition
description:
The Battle for Normandy, Deluxe Edition

The Battle for Normandy is a game that represents the climactic campaign in Normandy from D-Day, 6 June 1944 to the first week of August 1944 at primarily battalion level. Numerous scenarios are included to play out various smaller battles in Normandy. It is intended for two players or player teams.

- Campaign : 5 maps, 6 June - 10 Aug
- Bloody Omaha : part of one map, 6 June - 10 June
- Cobra : 2 maps (most of play on one though), 25 July - 31 July
- Goodwood & Cobra (combined): 4 maps, 18 July - 31 July
- Operation Epsom : 1 map, 26 June - 1 July
- The Battle for Cherbourg : 1 map, 18 June - 27 June

Game Features

TIME SCALE 6 hours per turn
MAP SCALE 1250 yards per hex
UNIT SCALE Battalion or Company

OF PLAYERS One to Six


Includes the original game and expansion combined, with a few new components.

New Components:
- 1 Random Events Table (8-1/2 x 11”) card stock
- 12 Interdiction level cards (2x3”, or regular card size)

It has been about twelve years since The Battle for Normandy was originally released. Since that time, new research has been made available, and the game has been played countless times by many players around the world who have provided a wealth of feedback. The game system remains basically the same, allowing players to focus on planning and strategy and not an overbearing rules system. Based on that new research and feedback, many units have been adjusted, all of the maps have minor changes, and some whole rules sections have been revamped to better represent the historical reality, while minimizing further complexity. The original expansion is included in this Deluxe Edition (while remaining optional), and there are also new scenarios.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Simulation

name: Stalemate Dice
description:
Stalemate Dice is the dice game where you play the role of the Germans or the British battling to gain control of the trenches. Fierce fighting will take place in and out of the trenches. Advancing out of your trench will make you an easy target, but will make your fire power more deadly. Watch out for gas attacks and bombardments, which can cause much damage to your troops. If you can break the stalemate and wipe out the enemy, you win! The fate of trenches begins with the roll of the dice.

Each turn, players can take 1 of six actions including re-positioning soldiers, bringing in reinforcements and treating the wounded to gain the advantage over your opponent. When your artillery is ready, create carnage in your opponent's ranks.

The first player to have their ranks dwindle to three active soldiers left on the board and or the spent dice board loses the game.
categories: Dice, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I

name: NANKU
description:
NANKU is a 3-dimensional game that uses a single ‘dual’ piece composed of two cubes of different colours.

In NANKU, players alternate turns placing or stacking pieces with the aim of creating a line of 4 cubes of their colour (a ‘nanku’). Each player has an allocated colour (White or Black). Place the 40 pieces within both player’s reach, but leaving room for the game on the playing surface.

Starting with White, players alternate turns placing one piece from the supply in any position (even standing vertically) following these placement rules:

a) The piece must align with the cubic grid.

b) It must be adjacent (two faces touching) to at least one already played piece, if any.

c) It must be fully supported by either the table or pieces below it; i.e. no overhangs are allowed.

The first player creating a line of 4 cubes of her colour wins the game. Lines can be horizontal, vertical or diagonal and any two consecutive cubes from that line must be touching each other by at least one edge (not only a vertex). Also all 4 cubes must have at least one exposed (visible) face.

If, at any moment, you knock a piece over, you immediately lose the game.

It is recommended to play on a surface that can be rotated, and you’re allowed to rotate it on your turn.

On your first plays, you’ll notice how black wins almost all the time. As you play more, then white will win most of the time (find the best opening for white). But once you gain more experience, games might last more than 30 turns and wins will balance out.
mechanics: Stacking and Balancing, Three Dimensional Movement

name: World of Tanks Miniatures Game: German – Tiger I
description:
Seen the movie Fury? Then you don’t need to know anything else about this iconic World War II tank. If not then trust us, it is good.

The Tiger I has solid stats with firepower 5 and initiative 4, but where it shines is the combination of Fortress (no penalty for being shot in the flank), survivability 2, and Heavy Tank (allowing you to re-roll a blank defense dice). Park this tank in front of your enemies and watch them sweat as shot after shot bounces.

Looking to lurk back in cover and pick your targets rather than tanking up frot? Add the gunner Erwin Prentzel to gain extra initiative in the shooting phase and extra defense whilst in cover.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: AdverCity
description:
PREPARE FOR AN ALL-OUT DOWNTOWN DEVASTATION!

In AdverCity, your duty is to lead your town to brighter days. The terrain your town is built on is often plagued with horrific and deadly disasters. As the newly elected mayor, you must push past the obstacles that lie before you and prepare your town for the impending doom. No one has succeeded thus far, but we believe in your ability to lead!

You must increase your cities' population, ensure that your citizens are well fed, and provide them with financial security. Will you overcome the challenges that lie ahead of you as mayor of this unfortunate town? Can you prepare your town and survive the imminent disasters that come your way?

AdverCity can be played with either 3 or 4 people. A 3 player game consists of 18 turns and a 4 player game consists of 14 turns. On each turn, a player rolls the dice to determine the resources everyone gets from their buildings on that turn. Once the resources are distributed to everyone, the player can buy more buildings, trade with others, and feed their population. Disaster rounds occur throughout the game dependent of the number of players. In order to win, a player must end the game with the highest population by protecting their citizens from various disasters. So, go out and save your town!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Random Production

name: Der Clou: Roll & Heist – The Great Train Robbery
description:
Like the basic game, the campaign is designed for 1-­3 players and includes a total of 4 new break­-ins. These are connected to each other by content and your gang of thieves gains more experience with each break-­in. You also have the opportunity to buy new tools and to prepare yourself with your loot.

This game is to help the small game stores through the time of closure. Order something online at your local game store and send a photo or scan of it to clou@boardgame-racoon.de. You will receive the "The great train robbery" campaign with 4 extra scenarios via email as soon as it is finished.
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Feline Felonies
description:
In Feline Felonies you take charge of a neighbourhood cat whose goal is to be the greatest thief around. You’ll steal toys and other items cats believe to be toys from around the board as well as from other cats. Get the most highly valued toys home to win and be crowned most felonious of the felines.

Players roll dice to determine their 'Purr Points' for each turn. Using these they traverse the board, pick up and drop off toys, steal toys from other cats and even increase the value of their toys. Whenever a cat tries to steal from another, dice are rolled to determine the 'reflexes' and 'stealth' for each to determine whether the theft was successful or not.

Special Actions linked to each number on the die allow players to move toys on the board, add new toys to the board, increase or decrease the value of toys by flipping the token or take a cat nap to save Purr Points for use later in the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Take That

name: Invizibell
description:
One player secretly moves around a grid, spelling words to take over a board.

The other player tries to work out where they are.
mechanics: Hidden Movement, Roles with Asymmetric Information, Variable Set-up

name: Poesía a la Carta: Gustavo Roldán
description:
A game to connect with the poetry of Gustavo Roldán.
As a poetic oracle, each poem, combined with the lunfardo, can offer us an answer.

Three forms of play: "poetry on demand", "poetic oracle" and "playing the game". Think of a question and poetry will answer you. Includes 10 letters with words from the lunfardo to complete the answer.

name: Samrajya
description:
Samrajya board game was created to engage people about Nepali traditions, history and culture.
It follows Prithvi Narayan Shah's journey to control the Kathmandu valley and unify Nepal.

Goal of the game:

move along the treacherous path and capture the four kingdoms:
Kirtipur,
Patan,
Bhaktapur,
Kathmandu

then claim the crown.


Gameplay:
Roll the dice and move.
Cards lets players attack other players, take their cards, switch positions etc... Only 1 card can be played, before or after rolling the dice.
mechanics: Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: Sunder
description:
Sunder is a drawless connection game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the spaces (cells) of an initially empty hexagonal grid of hexagons. Each player must have access to a sufficient number of stones of their own color.

A group is a set of mutually adjacent stones of the same color. A cut of a group is a set of mutually adjacent cells (empty or occupied by either color) including no stones in that group.

Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, place a stone of your color on an empty cell.

You win by making a group of your color such that none of its cuts include more than half of the cells on the board.



Komi and pie ruleKomi or the pie rule (or both) can be used in order to make the game fair.

The pie rule gives White the option, on their first turn only, to swap sides with their opponent instead of making a regular move.

Komi is either a whole number or a whole number plus 0.5. When komi is used, Black wins by making a black group such that none of its cuts include more than half of the cells on the board minus komi, and White wins by making a white group such that none of its cuts include more than half of the cells on the board plus komi.

Before the game starts, the first player chooses the value of komi, and then the second player chooses sides. Alternatively, experienced players may agree on a standard value for all games. When komi and the pie rule are used together, Black on their first turn chooses komi and places a black stone on the board, and then White has the option to swap sides with Black instead of making a regular move.



NotesSunder is a particular case of Omny.
mechanics: Connections, Enclosure, Hexagon Grid, Network and Route Building, Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Ninth Edition): Crusade Mission Pack – Amidst the Ashes
description:
This mission pack is a narrative play expansion for the Warhammer 40,000 Crusade campaign system.

Within this book, you’ll find the rules required to play games of Warhammer 40,000 set in the Charadon Sector, which continues to burn in the fires of war as the Chaos and Imperial forces pour fresh forces into the escalating conflict.

This mission pack has been specifically designed for use in narrative play Crusade games, where your campaigning forces can battle across the war-torn worlds of Kolossi, Fathom, and Metalica. With plagues running amok and devastating new weaponry being brought to bear on every front, will your Crusade force rise to prominence or buckle beneath the weight of the terrible conflict?

This 112-page mission pack includes:

Six new missions each for Combat Patrol-, Incursion-, Strike Force- and Onslaught-sized games.
A selection of new Amidst the Ashes Agendas, Requisitions, Stratagems, and more
The basic rules for Warhammer 40,000 – designed to be quickly referenced during your games


You will need a copy of the Warhammer 40,000 Core Book to use the contents of this mission pack.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Mord in Richman Hall
description:
Who has the Earl of Rich on his conscience? The players slip into the roles of Lady Abigail & Co. and investigate the murderer. Not an easy task, because everyone present would have had reason enough to send "Uncle Rich" to the afterlife. And since teatime and dinner are as much a part of the British landed gentry as tweed jackets and ladies' hats, the ladies and gentlemen also reveal their favorite feasts.

—user summary

name: The Ghost in the Attic
description:
Can you play the haunted game and banish the ghost forever?

Terrible things happened to those who played this haunted board game when it was released in the 1950s. But the only way to solve the mystery is to play the game yourself.

Similar to an escape room game, this mystery presents you with a replica board game, chained up with a metal combination lock, and leaves you to work out how to open it and find and solve the mystery.

name: Gambit of Kings
description:
Gambit of Kings is an exciting game of strategy and conquest! It combines the classic feel of chess with the atmosphere of a medieval fantasy world. You must use strategy and cunning to lead your armies to victory and overtake your opponent’s castle!

To begin, you and your opponent must setup the board and choose a random means to determine who will move first. Players then alternate moves. When it is your turn to move, you must move exactly one of your pieces. You can’t move to a space occupied by one of your other pieces, and you can’t “jump” over any pieces unless otherwise specified. If you move to a space occupied by one of your opponent’s pieces, his or her piece is destroyed. Once you move, your turn is over. The first player to destroy his or her opponent’s Castle wins the game.

Players can choose to play with the standard gameboard setup or customize the board with new and unique game pieces from expansion packs.

—description from the designer

name: 221B Baker St.: Sherlock Holmes & the Time Machine – Set #2
description:
An additional set of cases for 221B Baker St.: Sherlock Holmes & the Time Machine. This package comprises cases #21-40:

21. The speeding bullet (1959)
22. The forty whacks (1892)
23. The final flight (1937)
24. Even blondes get the blues (1962)
25. Death of a dream (1968)
26. The twisted cord (1977)
27. The bushy-haired man (1954)
28. The Candy Man's Wife (1977)
29. The flamingo's curse (1947)
30. The blood-stained laundryman (1929)
31. The empty bench (1930)
32. The body on the beach (1931)
33. The sea-tac slayings (1980's)
34. The vicar's last sermon (1924)
35. The right field shot (1988)
36. The nebulous nuggets (1949)
37. The jolly girls' lament (1967)
38. The president's man (1993)
39. The buried hatchet (1918)
40. The walking corpse (1935)
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Murder/Mystery, Novel-based

name: BLASTER: Games Anthology 03
description:
BLASTER: Vol. 3 includes an exclusive standalone game, Sludge War, and four expansions:


Sludge War (Standalone Game) - Sludge is a complete and incredibly rich standalone game. Massive armies are on the march in an unceasing conflict that shadows over humanity, and even the environment, grinding it all down into a pulp. It is 52 pages of inglorious black powder plus gaming at its finest.



Shadowgrave Part II - Official Expansion for Rangers of Shadow Deep, Frostgrave, and Frostgrave: Ghost Archipelago. The worlds of Rangers of Shadow Deep and Frostgrave are being invaded from unfathomable horrors that their heroes can barely stand up against. Will you wield magic to defend against the darkest threat your world has seen? And at what cost are you willing to do so?



Gaslands: Legacy - Official Campaign Expansion for Gaslands: Refuelled. Earth gets an eviction notice from Mars, and becomes dismantled and reassembled into a progressively more chaotic post-post-apocalyptic world. Randomly generate an illegal build and get out of the factory fast before you become dismantled yourself. Unique LEGACY Gaslands rules, and five awesome narrative scenarios. Find out more here.



Gamma Wolves: Ronin - Official Expansion for Gamma Wolves - Mecha pilots vie for dwindling resources on a post-apocalyptic earth. What path will your mercenary pilot take? Will she follow The Path of the Guardian and fight to protect her team? Will she follow the Path of the Sword and down enemy mechs in honorable combat? Or will she prefer to stalk her prey with the Path of the Hunter?



The Mysterious Anomalies of Site-X - Official Expansion for This is Not a Test. Truly unpredictable anomalies plague Site-X, a supplement for This is Not a Test. Will your quest for some of the rarest and powerful artifacts aid your survival or send your models flying across the board into a wall, or even being shred up into indiscernible viscera?


This PDF document presents print-and-play expansion modules for the miniatures games noted above.

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Print & Play
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Measurement Movement, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Bowline
description:
Bowline is played on a hexhex board with stones of two colors, one color belonging to each player. The winner of the game is the player to first make a loop consisting entirely of stones of their color.

Rules:
On your turn, you must either (i) place a stone of your color on an empty hex, or (ii) flip an eligible arc of enemy stones. You may not do both.

Definitions:
To flip an enemy stone is to replace it with a stone of your own, from your (preferably endless) supply.

An arc is a possibly bent line of stones with no acute angles and no turns going in opposite directions (no S-like swingyness). (Se below for a more precise definition of an arc.)

You are said to flank an arc of enemy pieces if two of your pieces are the endpoints of an arc otherwise completely made up of said enemy pieces.

You may flip an arc of enemy pieces if you are the only one flanking it.

A loop is a group of stones causing one or more cells not contained in that group to be severed from the edges of the board in this sense: There is no chain of adjacent cells going from any of those severed cells to any edge cell that does not contain at least one stone from the loop group. (It's a curve of stones biting itself in the ass, around at least one enemy stone or at least one empty cell.)

More precise definition of an arc:
A chain of adjacent pieces make up an arc if it is possible to order them from first to last in a sequence where a walk from the first to the last member of the chain, visiting all members in order, will (i) at no point require a turn of more than 60 degrees, and (ii) either require no clockwise turns or no counter-clockwise turns.

—description from the designer

name: Unknot
description:
Unknot is played on a hexhex board oriented so that there is a horizontal line of adjacent cells between one pair of two opposing corner cells.

Both players share a pool of stones of a single color and take turns placing then onto empty cells.

Placement restrictions.

The center cell is unplayable throughout the game.
Player 1 may not place immediately northwest of a stone.
Player 2 may not place immediately northeast of a stone.


The game is over as soon as one player completes a loop of pieces around at least one empty cell. This player is then the winner. The game cannot end in a draw, so can also be played with the opposite goal: The player who completes a loop loses.

—description from the designer

name: Song of the Seas
description:
You are a privateer seeking to make your fortune. The tyrannical Imperial Navy is threatening to invade and conquer your island home, robbing you and all the people of the islands of their freedom. The Empire has no mercy, and has swiftly branded you and the other privateers as pirates. It is up to you to gain renown by seeking adventure and facing numerous perils, becoming strong enough to rule these islands and repel the Imperial Navy from these waters. There are other privateers with the same goal as you, and while you all share a similar goal, only one of you can earn the most renown and become the Pirate King or Queen.

Song of the Seas is a pirate adventure sandbox game in which you must stake your claim over the islands by building your Lair and earning the most renown. Sink ships of the tyrannical Imperial Navy, plunder merchant vessels, explore for booty, and encounter legendary perils on the high seas. And don’t forget to choose the right shanty for your crew to sing each day for special boons!

Your goal in Song of the Seas is to earn the most Renown. The game end is triggered when one player reaches 20 Renown, in which that game round (“Day”) is then completed and final scores tallied. You also earn 1 Renown for every 100 Gold doubloons you have at the end of the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Exploration, Fighting, Music, Nautical, Pirates
mechanics: Action/Event, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Events, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Pieces as Map, Re-rolling and Locking, Solo / Solitaire Game, Square Grid, Stat Check Resolution, Turn Order: Time Track

name: The Aquabats!: Super Showdown!
description:
In The Aquabats! Super Showdown! card game, two to four players are villains competing to capture all five members of The Aquabats, the world's greatest superhero rock band.

The game consists of three types of cards: Monster cards, Action cards, and Aquabats cards. Monster cards have colors and power levels. Each turn, a player plays a Monster card and draws a new Monster card. If the card played is of the same color and a higher power level than the card previously played, that player may draw both a Monster card and an Action card. At the start of a player's turn, a Battle card or Epic Battle card may be played, challenging one player or all players respectively to a showdown. Each player in the battle must play a Monster card, and the winner may take an Aquabat card from the table or, if none remain, steal one from the defeated player.

Shrink Ray cards enable a challenged player to diminish the power of an aggressor; X-Ray cards allow one to peak at another player's hand; Antibats cards foil the winner of a battle from taking a loser's Aquabat card; and Steal cards can be used to acquire another player's Aquabat card without a battle.

Play continues until one player acquires all five Aquabat cards or until War is mutually declared, in which case the winner of a single round Epic Battle is declared the game's victor.

name: Vacu
description:
Vacu is a Go-like territory game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board. Each player must have access to a sufficient number of stones of their own color.



DefinitionsIn these rules, "adjacent" always means "orthogonally adjacent".

A group is a stone along with all other like-colored stones one could reach from it through a series of steps between adjacent stones of its color.

Similarly, a territory is an empty point along with all other empty points one could reach from it through a series of steps between adjacent empty cells. You own a territory if all stones adjacent to points in that territory are of your color.

A liberty of a group is an empty point adjacent to at least one stone in that group.

To flip a group is to replace all its stones with stones of the opposite color.

To suppress a group is to remove all its stones from the board.

Your score is the number of stones of your color on the board, plus the number of points in your territories, plus komi (see below) if you play White.



PlayBlack plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, pass or place a stone of your color on an empty point. If this stone is part of a group with liberties, suppress all enemy groups without liberties. Otherwise, suppress your group without liberties and flip all enemy groups that had no liberties before the suppression. In the latter case, at least one group must be flipped for the move to be legal.

The game ends when either both players pass in succession or a player flips or suppresses the last enemy group on the board. The player with the higher score in the final position wins. The button is used to avoid ties.

If, after a board play, the same board position appears for the third time with the same player to move, the game ends in a draw. A pass is not a board play.



Komi and buttonKomi is the whole number of points which is added to White's score at the end of the game as a compensation for playing second. Before the game starts, the first player chooses the value of komi, and then the second player chooses sides. Alternatively, experienced players may agree on a standard value for all games.

The button is a special token which is placed next to the board at the start of the game. On your turn, if neither player has taken the button yet, you may not pass, but you may take the button instead of making a board play. At the end of the game, a half point is added to the score of the player who has taken the button. When checking for repetitions, two identical board positions are still considered different if the button had already been taken in one of them but not in the other.



VariantsConvacu: The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white. If you have no other moves available, you must pass. Passing is otherwise not allowed. If, at the end of a turn, there is a group touching the two opposite board edges of its color, the owner of that group wins.
mechanics: Enclosure, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Nase vorn
description:
In this game, published by Deutsche Bahn and produced by Ravensburger, players travel within Germany by train, car or plane (and have to pay the costs).
Players choose different modes of transportation to reach their destination as quickly as possible. For reaching the destinations, players receive points that they are allowed to drag forward on the time path. The sooner a player arrives at the destination, the more additional time points he wins. If a player runs out of money, he can spend time to earn some more bucks. The game ends after 6 trips. The winner is the player who is ahead on the time path.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Ninja Knights
description:
In the time of war during the Sengoku period in Japan, four clans vie for control of Sakura Village from its brutal leader, Lord Ishihara.

Ninja Knights is a deck-building action-adventure game. Each player plays as a ninja from one of the competing dojos. The ninja use their decks to control all their actions and complete missions toward victory. They scramble through the random village tiles teeming with enemy samurai and guards. By building up and increasing power with items and ability cards, the ninja race to spy, rescue, and assassinate.

Sneaking and Combat is done by building up combos within the player’s hand.

The enemy actions are controlled by a cube-pull system, which keeps players on their toes. The guards and samurai are constantly moving throughout the village. A simple guard may carry the heart of a lion. While a samurai could easily become something even worse!

Purchasing the many different items from the shops and upgrades from the temple and shrine allow each ninja to focus on their own style. Plus, completed mission cards join the player’s deck for a greater bonus and more buying power.

Ninja Knights uses a streamlined A.I. Ninja that fights to complete missions herself. This evil ninja allows solo play or she can add an extra challenger in two or three player games.

Components included:

1 Rulebook

120+ Poker Cards

16 4”x 4" Boards

12 Blue tokens

14 Red tokens

4 White tokens

12 Yellow tokens

2 Eight-sided Dice

1 Compass Die

2 Green markers

2 Orange markers

2 White markers

3 Ninja Meeples

2 Clear Markers

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Hidden Victory Points, Movement Points, Solo / Solitaire Game, Square Grid

name: Don't Look Back: Death on the Line Expansion
description:
You don't want to find yourself on the wrong side of the old Sealy Line this time. It starts with a 'choo-choo' and ends with a chop! Boxcar Willy is back in all his chainsaw glory with DEATH ON THE LINE. There's guaranteed to be viscera flying and train whistles tolling in this action-packed slasher adventure. Just remember, Willy's hungry and looking for fresh meat to smoke.

—description from the publisher

This expansion adds 1 Boxcar Willy Killer miniature and 2 custom scenarios to the base game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement

name: Emperor!
description:
Emperor! is a eurogame-style game that takes place in 11th century Constantinople, and is centred around the battle for the imperial throne.

Emperor! has a unique two-phase feature. In phase one players move around a map of the city collecting money, military units and characters to build up their faction. Game play is card-based, with simultaneous turns, so bluff and negotiation are important.

Then, in phase two, the board flips over to a simple, diagrammatic battlefield. The players cash in their cards and sets to buy more military units. These are deployed face-down on the battle map. Players then select tactical cards (outflank, charge! etc) for their army and combat is resolved.

Emperor! is card-based with no dice. It takes 30-90 minutes to play.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Art Smart
description:
Art Smart is an art auction game for 3-5 players in which all players buy and sell art – but watch out for fake pieces.

Depending on the number of players each player gets dealt a number of Painting cards and an equal number of Fake/Real cards.

Every round of the game is an auction where a Painting card gets auctioned off in which the auctioneer participates as well. After the painting is sold and the money is handed over, it's established if the painting was Real or Fake and the Artist's value goes up or down.

After all Paintings are auctioned the game ends and the player who owns the combined highest value of Paintings wins.

—description from the designer

name: Topside Miniature Naval Warfare
description:
These are the Topside Miniature Naval Warfare Rules accompany our naval miniature sets, and are offered as a basic framework for using and enjoying the miniatures. We tried for the emphasis on playability while giving the player a healthy does of realism. If you are reading this sentence right now, you are probably reading it on paper or in electronic form, rather than written on stone. So read these rules, take the miniatures for a spin, and adjust the battle table to your liking. Season to taste, as the cookbooks say. And enjoy!
